review_title: So much potential for good things: Hard working staff committed to student success!
pros: Students make their lives better every day . . . lots of engaged faculty, organizational commitment to help new students make it to the completion of their desired program or degree. Salary and benefits are phenomenal if you can land a full-time position. Lots of vacation, holidays and even paid snow days (within limits!). pros: Some very cool, hard-working staff who really do care about serving the student, but not nearly enough.
cons: The only thing left out of the title is that faculty reign supreme here. The instructors answer to precisely no one. Therefore, the student has no meaningful recourse if an instructor makes a mistake on their Education plan, grades punitively, is disorganized, a poor communicator, or is just a jerk. And last, but not least the communication between departments that is necessary to give the student the best possible direction and experience is non existent.

pros: Pay was so-so, but full-timers get way more for the exact same job. Co-workers were usually nice.
cons:
Constant micromanagement from upper levels. Department "managers" don't actually manage anything and have no authority. All management decisions from large to very small, come from someone who does not, and has likely never, worked in the department they supervise. Employee reviews are more often than not coming from someone the employee has never met. Inefficiency is rampant and the entire place is top-heavy. Because Supervisors are not given enough to do, they take an inordinate interest in the minutiae of the departments under them, and by email, waste everyone's time with silly "kudos" and meaningless congratulations for handling large volumes of students in a small amounts of time with no regard for how long the students waited for services from an understaffed department that could have used an extra set of hands should they have been less busy with writing silly emails. This inordinate interest also encourages a kind of immaturity in the employees (since nothing is ever their responsibility). They use any free time they have to tattle on each other to their supervisors instead of maturely working out their minor differences like adults. Since no one is encouraged to take responsibility for anything that is not listed specifically in their job description (in fact, they are discouraged from doing anything extra) needed work remains undone, including callbacks, face-to-face student contact, and office cleanup. 

Oh! and the worst con of all--the college (believe it or not) does not have a decent incentive program for staff to take their own classes. Instead they have a ridiculously complicated system for getting 3 credits at a time (not enough for even one class). The staff member must pay for all the rest and, unlike most colleges, even this piddly benefit is not transferable to family members. This makes the staff at MHCC the most poorly educated staff around and their students, after even one year of college, superior in education to the majority of the MHCC staff. So much for encouraging higher education!

job_title: Business Office Stooge in New York, NY
pros: The majority of employees are talented and are willing to go above and beyond for students and each other. The benefit package is generous. A handful of Managers are supportive and willing to stand behind their subordinates. Many Faculty members are skilled and treat students and classified members well.
cons: Their is a core group of administrators and directors who treat the school as their private country club. Funds are wasted on pet projects (while claiming poverty) including a coffee shop in the library even though there are three other existing coffee shops on campus. A pay-to-park program was short lived and scrapped soon after implantation. The software included annual maintenance which is still paid for even though the ticket dispensers have been warehoused for years. The program was pointed out to be a poor choice prior to the purchase but those at the top moved forward shrugging their shoulders when it predictably failed. When students balked at paying to park and took Tri-Met a "campus access fee" was instituted. The Aquatics Center is rarely open to the public though a staggering amount of money is spent each year to set-up then tear-down a pneumatic dome over the outdoor pool. Classified members who become "yes men" receive favorable treatment while those who aren't in that group are bullied until they inevitably quit or are put on a "plan" which consists of Herculean tasks ending in their termination. Public Safety is virtually non-existent (do to poor management) in the evening as one officer is tasked with the entire campus. The Grounds and Custodial Departments are amazingly understaffed though there always seems to be funding for yet another overpaid administrator. The Faculty were spoiled rotten under a previous President and some have become quite comfortable with abusing Classified members. Those particular Faculty members have an attitude of "Do you know who I am? Don't you understand I have a Masters/PhD?" There is a great deal of lip service given by the Administration regarding "a culture of respect". In reality back stabbing and blatant lying is the order of the day for upper Management. So many good employees have been driven out or terminated by petty little tyrants wielding their power like drunken monarchs. The only real hope for long term employees is for another institution to purchase the school and fire everyone at the manager level and up. The board is either inept or negligent, they seem to either turn a blind eye to glaring problems or are so caught up in getting their names in the paper as to not care. The Facilities are literally falling apart due to kicking the can down the road. Take a look at the holes in the ceiling throughout the outdoor common areas. Make sure you have an escape plan if you dare to enter any of the arts buildings.
